data.title: Syntax highlighting fails after opening bracket on the new line
VSCode extensions can lock asar files
data.body:
I‚Äôve given you (bpasero) access to my private repo.  https://github.com/a11smiles/azure-orchestrator

I‚Äôm developing on Windows 10.  It‚Äôs an Electron app built with Angular2 & Typescript.  `npm start` will run gulp which deletes and rebuilds the `dist` subfolder.  The `dist` folder has 3 distros of the app in its output subfolder ‚Äì Linux, OSX, Windows.  Each one of these folders has a `resources` subfolder that contains an .asar file.

I‚Äôve added the `dist` folder to my ignored folders in VSCode in hopes that code would just ignore the whole folder.  While the `dist` folder no longer shows up in the list of folders in VSCode, there‚Äôs still a lock placed on the .asar files.

Steps to reproduce:

1)      In the main folder: `npm start`
2)      Let it build
3)      Open VSCode on the folder: `code .`
4)      Wait a minute or two
5)      Now, with VSCode still open on the folder, attempt to build again: ‚Äònpm start‚Äô
6)      You should get an error saying that gulp could not delete the `dist` folder due to VSCode having locks on the .asar files

data.title: Markdown preview loses scrollbar on edit
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Markdown file, long enough to have a scrollbar in its preview
2. Open preview to the side
3. Edit the file

The preview loses the scrollbar once it refreshes due to the file change event.

data.title: Trigger signature help after completion
data.body:
In my case completion for functions also insert the parenthesis ( e.g. `foo({{}})`)
For signature help I have the triggerCharacter `'('` but unfortunately inserting it by applying a suggestion doesn't trigger signature help. 
Is there a way to have signature help triggered when applying a completion suggestion?

Hover could be more readable in this case

2. Hover over constructor
3. I think the hover could somehow be more readable, all these constructor arguments one after the other are not helping - could we colorize better?

data.title: Watermark: layerbreaks
data.body:
I noticed `watermark.ts` and `watermark.css` in `vs/workbench/parts/watermark` which comes with some issues:
- first of all there should be a parent folder for those that outlines the target execution environment (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Code-Organization). just take a look how other parts do it
- then, parts is typically a contribution to the workbench and no code from vs/workbench should depend on it (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Code-Organization#workbench-parts)

I suggest to rewrite the watermark to be a workbench extension (such as `UpdateContribution` in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/update/electron-browser/update.contribution.ts#L38) and do it all cleanly via services.

To get access to the editor container HTML element I suggest to add a new method to the `IPartService` (which `workbench.ts` implements) to return the HTML element for a given part (e.g. `getContainer(partId)`).

I can help you out in case of questions üëç

data.title: Project Search/Replace with RegExp with \n only searches in currently open file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 and 1.6.0-insiders

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open project-wide search/replace
2. Enable regexp searching
3. Type in a search that includes a new line, like `<\?php\n\nnamespace`
4. Hit enter => no results
5. Open a file where the pattern occurs, like
   
   ``` php
   <?php
   
   namespace Whatever;
   ```
6. Hit enter again => one result _only_ in this open file
7. Remove `\n\n` from query
8. Hit enter again => all results (files) show up

data.title: Allow to open multiple project folders in the same window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a project folder in the editor
2. Now drag and drop another project folder in the same window
3. Observe that the previously open project is replaced with the new dragged and dropped project folder

Expectation: 
1. Just like editors like Sublime Brackets Atom, multiple project folders need to hooked to the tree in the left side bar

data.title: simplify configuration resolver
Internal terminal buffersize too small
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 7

Although the buffersize of "C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe" is set to 5000 the internal terminal does not use it. It is not possible to scroll up to the beginning of the produced output when its to long. A possiblity to control the buffersize in the settings-file would be nice (I couldn't find it)

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Create a long output  >700 lines
2. Try to read the beginning of the output

data.title: If eval is evil, then what is new Function()?
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/release/1.5/src/vs/workbench/parts/lib/node/configVariables.ts#L33

So... what will happen if `name` is `foo[process.exit()]`?

Why not simply do:

```
newValue = config[name];
```

?

data.title: VScode editor .xml file extension to show html file inside editor
data.body:
@joaomoreno 
- VSCode Version: *
- OS Version: Windows/Linux

I'm new to vscode editor, I need below functionality to extended vscode editor.

How to render and display html file inside a vscode editor depending on file extension type.

Suppose following is the folder structure.

```
> MyProject[folder]
   > src[folder]
   > lib[folder]
   > package.json[file]
   > config.xml[file]
```

When user clicks on config.xml file I want to open an index.html file inside vscode editor(may be in preview window or any other option). Html file should be displayed as how it displays in browser inside vscode not as how editor displays as an editing html file.

data.title: Auto add import statements as part of code completion
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.x
- OS Version: Win7

Please auto add import statements as part of code completion. I find that with large class files, having to scroll to the top and write a import statement to be a huge time sink. I must have done this same task a few hundred times now. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create 2 ts files with exported classes
2. In the 2nd class, create an instance of the 1st class. 
3. Expect that an 'import x from y' statement is automatically added, but this isn't the case.

data.title: Wrong language with definition preview hover
data.body:
It seems that when a definition preview is shown in a hover (on ‚åò+hover), it is assumed that the location occurs in a file of the same language as the origin position. Since this is not always the case, the result can be incorrectly highlighted.

I think a straightforward way to address this would be to allow specifying an optional `language` field (like for `MarkedString`) along with the returned `Location`.

data.title: Output to the debug console from a PowerShell script stops at some random point
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Win10.1607

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run a powershell script (I observed that behaviour on a couple of very different scripts)
2. At some point output to the debug console stops, though the script finishes just fine.

data.title: Code screen scrolls with output screen
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with a fresh run of VSCode.  If you've already had the Output screen and an editor open, this will not reproduce.
2. Build a task to run an external build command.  Something like something like:

```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "sh",
    "args": ["-c"],
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "build mycode",
            "args": ["build.sh my_project"]
        }
    ]
}
```

Build.sh essentially calls make on each sub-directory before it moves on to linking and spills the output on the screen.
3. Open a large-ish C/CPP file in the editor (couple thousand lines).  
4. Run the build task.
5. Watch as the build task fills up the output window and starts to scroll, the text in the above editor will increment line by line with the task output buffer filling.

data.body: Open a markdown file. Have the cursor somewhere. Move it somewhere else with the arrow keys, then press cmd+shift+v to 'open markdown preview'. Press cmd+shift+v again. Now the cursor is in a different place. Similar to the bugs like #11727 I guess.

data.title: Correctly Support accessing config values in launch.config
data.body:
Issue #13051

Correctly handles config object paths in the `"${config.PATH}"` values. This adds support for cases like: `"${config[0]}"` or `"${config['abc']}"`

Closes #13051

- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

E.g. ${config['foo']} does not work while ${config.bar['foo']} does.

data.title: Closing Developer Tools closes entire application and skips unsaved changes prompt
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.3 (5be4091987a98e3870d89d630eb87be6d9bafd27, 2016-09-22T08:50:42.185Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a new instance of VS Code.
2. Type something in the "Untitled-1" tab to set an "Unsaved Changes" state.
3. Help > Toggle Developer Tools.
4. Click the 'X' in the top-right of the Developer Tools view.
5. Help > Toggle Developer Tools.
6. Click the 'X' in the top-right of the Developer Tools view.
7. VS Code closes, unsaved changes prompt is not displayed, and unsaved changes are lost.
